summary: William K. Harvey was a CIA personnel member assigned to the Berlin Base, as indicated by Robert Glenn Thompson's recollection from his time with OSI, Berlin. Documents related to Harvey include a New York Times obituary, correspondence regarding his retirement from the CIA, and personnel action requests detailing his assignments and salary adjustments. He was issued Federal Aviation Agency Credential Number 4883 on January 2, 1963. Harvey's testimony on June 25, 1975, outlines details related to Operation ZRRIFLE, focusing on the recruitment, development, and security protocols for clandestine agents, and mentions individuals and operations related to the JFK assassination. He was interviewed by David W. Belin concerning his background and knowledge of assassination plots within the CIA. FBI interviews in March 1963 pertained to various individuals associated with the CIA, focusing on topics such as CIA efforts to penetrate the USSR and details about the Technical Aids Detachment (TAD) in Frankfurt, Germany. Robert Glenn Thompson provided information about Harvey to the Soviets.
significance: William K. Harvey's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from his involvement in Operation ZRRIFLE and his knowledge of assassination plots within the CIA, as indicated by his testimony and interviews. The documents suggest he had a role in clandestine operations and was potentially knowledgeable about sensitive information related to the assassination.
